lines.text: Enter ANTIPHOLUS of Syracuse, DROMIO of Syracuse, and First Merchant

lines.speaker: first merchant
lines.text: Therefore give out you are of Epidamnum, Lest that your goods too soon be confiscate. This very day a Syracusian merchant Is apprehended for arrival here And not being able to buy out his life According to the statute of the town, Dies ere the weary sun set in the west. There is your money that I had to keep. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Go bear it to the Centaur, where we host, And stay there, Dromio, till I come to thee. Within this hour it will be dinnertime: Till that, Ill view the manners of the town, Peruse the traders, gaze upon the buildings, And then return and sleep within mine inn, For with long travel I am stiff and weary. Get thee away.

lines.speaker: dromio of syracuse
lines.text: Many a man would take you at your word, And go indeed, having so good a mean. ANTIPHOLUS
Exit

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: A trusty villain, sir, that very oft, When I am dull with care and melancholy, Lightens my humour with his merry jests. What, will you walk with me about the town, And then go to my inn and dine with me

lines.speaker: first merchant
lines.text: I am invited, sir, to certain merchants, Of whom I hope to make much benefit I crave your pardon. Soon at five oclock, Please you, Ill meet with you upon the mart And afterward consort you till bedtime: My present business calls me from you now. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Farewell till then: I will go lose myself And wander up and down to view the city.

lines.speaker: first merchant
lines.text: Sir, I commend you to your own content. ANTIPHOLUS
Exit

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: He that commends me to mine own content Commends me to the thing I cannot get. I to the world am like a drop of water That in the ocean seeks another drop, Who, falling there to find his fellow forth, Unseen, inquisitive, confounds himself: So I, to find a mother and a brother, In quest of them, unhappy, lose myself. Here comes the almanac of my true date. What now how chance thou art returnd so soon
Enter DROMIO of Ephesus

lines.speaker: dromio of ephesus
lines.text: Returnd so soon! rather approachd too late: The capon burns, the pig falls from the spit, The clock hath strucken twelve upon the bell My mistress made it one upon my cheek: She is so hot because the meat is cold The meat is cold because you come not home You come not home because you have no stomach You have no stomach having broke your fast But we that know what tis to fast and pray Are penitent for your default today. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Stop in your wind, sir: tell me this, I pray: Where have you left the money that I gave you

lines.speaker: dromio of ephesus
lines.text: O,sixpence, that I had o Wednesday last To pay the saddler for my mistress crupper The saddler had it, sir I kept it not. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: I am not in a sportive humour now: Tell me, and dally not, where is the money We being strangers here, how darest thou trust So great a charge from thine own custody

lines.speaker: dromio of ephesus
lines.text: I pray you, air, as you sit at dinner: I from my mistress come to you in post If I return, I shall be post indeed, For she will score your fault upon my pate. Methinks your maw, like mine, should be your clock, And strike you home without a messenger. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Come, Dromio, come, these jests are out of season Reserve them till a merrier hour than this. Where is the gold I gave in charge to thee

lines.speaker: dromio of ephesus
lines.text: To me, sir why, you gave no gold to me. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Come on, sir knave, have done your foolishness, And tell me how thou hast disposed thy charge.

lines.speaker: dromio of ephesus
lines.text: My charge was but to fetch you from the mart Home to your house, the Phoenix, sir, to dinner: My mistress and her sister stays for you. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: In what safe place you have bestowd my money, Or I shall break that merry sconce of yours That stands on tricks when I am undisposed: Where is the thousand marks thou hadst of me

lines.speaker: dromio of ephesus
lines.text: I have some marks of yours upon my pate, Some of my mistress marks upon my shoulders, But not a thousand marks between you both. If I should pay your worship those again, Perchance you will not bear them patiently. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Thy mistress marks what mistress, slave, hast thou

lines.speaker: dromio of ephesus
lines.text: Your worships wife, my mistress at the Phoenix She that doth fast till you come home to dinner, And prays that you will hie you home to dinner. ANTIPHOLUS

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: What, wilt thou flout me thus unto my face, Being forbid There, take you that, sir knave.

lines.speaker: dromio of ephesus
lines.text: What mean you, sir for Gods sake, hold your hands! Nay, and you will not, sir, Ill take my heels. ANTIPHOLUS
Exit

lines.speaker: of syracuse
lines.text: Upon my life, by some device or other The villain is oerraught of all my money. They say this town is full of cozenage, As, nimble jugglers that deceive the eye, Darkworking sorcerers that change the mind, Soulkilling witches that deform the body, Disguised cheaters, prating mountebanks, And many suchlike liberties of sin: If it prove so, I will be gone the sooner. Ill to the Centaur, to go seek this slave: I greatly fear my money is not safe.
Exit
